results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about the banning of "Brave New World" in Ireland and Australia in 1932:

## Ireland (1932)
The novel was first banned in Ireland in 1932 for anti-religion, anti-family, and blasphemous content. Multiple sources confirm that the first instance of censorship occurred in Ireland in 1932, almost immediately after its publication, when the novel was banned on the grounds that it was deemed "blasphemous" and "indecent".

## Australia (1932)
Australia quickly followed by censoring the book in the same year. More specifically, Australia banned this book in 1932 as well, due to being anti-religious, anti-family and "extremely blasphemous" but it was removed from the list in 1937. Another source confirms that the novel was banned in Ireland and Australia in 1932, with the latter maintaining its censorship for five years.

## Broader Context
In 1932 it was banned in Australia and Ireland for language that was believed to go against familial and religious values, and most notably, the novel was first banned in Ireland when it was first published for what the country considered to be anti-family and anti-religious content.

The censorship reasons you mentioned in your query - anti-religion, anti-family, and blasphemous content - are accurately reflected in the historical record. Both Ireland and Australia acted quickly to ban the book in 1932, the same year it was published, primarily citing these moral and religious concerns.
